item.title: Learning Spanish 1
item.description:
Last week I decided to lean Spanish, roughly according to the study plan of Tommo Valkonen. First of, some history about why I want to do this:

My interest in languages started when I was some time into learning Esperanto and I found out that such endeavors – learning a language – are not necessarily horrible. I began to play around with foreign grammar and looked into some other constructed languages and finally Icelandic, which I learned – and still learn – to some extend. However, I soon met the desire to speak a more conventionally useful language and began to study Arabic in parallel to Icelandic and a full university schedule. This was obviously not planned through and I soon dropped it. So, what easy but useful languages are out there? The list is quite short: Spanish, French, and Polish for family reasons. I don’t currently want to put up with French spelling and pronunciation, which leaves the other two. Reading the memrise blog post mentioned above, I decided that a 6 week programme fits right into my schedule: starting on May 8th and ending on June 25th, with a week of interruption to go cycling in Norway.

According to the plan, I first learn the alphabet and pronunciation of the language (yup, took an hour or so). The next step is to learn the most common words, so that I have a base for further learning. After that, I’ll learn basic grammar and create some sentences. The rest of the time, practice with real people over the internet. As an introvert, this will be the hardest part for me, I really hope I’m going to follow through with this.

Last week, I used memrise to learn the 1000 most common Spanish words. I heavily recommend memrise for vocab learning, but even for oft-learned languages like Spanish, not all top listed courses are really good. The number of learners is a good first indication of course quality, but I recommend looking at the course forum to find out how the course creator reacts to correction proposals. A good course also provides information about the words (e.g. gender), but doesn’t force you to always type the relevant markers and accepts alternative versions of words and other words with the same meaning. For learning, I recommend practicing daily (with obvious exceptions for vacations and special events). This is independent of your time frame to learn the language. If you really don’t find motivation to learn on a specific date, just repeat one or two words and call it a day.

I don’t know when I’ll publish the next progress report, because there will be a lot to do at the end of the next week. Final presentation for Bachelor’s degree, preparation for holiday, and all. Expect something by June 4th. I published this post without corrections, because I wouldn’t publish it at all would I force myself to make it perfect. Nonetheless, mayme you found it interesting or even motivating to start learning a language yourself.

item.title: The Grove
item.description:
Birch grove. Two trees in front of you, one left and two more to the sides. Behind them fields of wheat, glowing yellow and ripe into the lightly clouded autumn skies. The morning sun shines through the translucent leaves and lets you experience an intense play of light and shadow between weeds and birches. To the right a raven lets his call sound over the peaceful field. None but you and him are present, each ignoring the other with benevolent indifference. An uncaringness as can only be offered to life with such different aspirations as between man and bird.

With your left foot you nearly stumble over a rectangular stone, two by four handspans on ground and one in height. A curious hollow shape carved in the middle, giving the impression of an ancient ritual place. A druid would certainly know the magic of this copse, but today it simply invites the lonely traveller to rest sometime, just a few steps away from the road behind you.

You realize that you hardly remember the aim of your travels, even the existence of the road. You get the feeling that you have forgotten something, and while you turn back to the road a darkness dawns on you, both in the rising of a thought and in the corner of your eye. The road! You have forgotten the road and now its world has forgotten you.

The darkness you sense is the shadow of the forest before you, the innumerous amount of pine trees stretching to infinity. You know there only ever were a handful of them between you and the road, but now their dark green needles stand mocking and merciless, amplifying your desperation.

The raven cries again and blight befalls the trees. You never close your eyes, but somehow the change in your environment escapes your perception: Three barren pines stand before a batch of dirt. Dirt and puddles – both quite familiar to your eye – stretching from horizon to horizon, guiding your gaze through the golden fields of wheat. The raven blinks at you, turns, and flies away.

item.title: Home
item.description:
Home

You leave the cosy hut and go outside into the cold. A few steps through thigh-high snow and darkness, then your eyes get used to the dimm moon light and you see the mountains rising up even higher than your already elevated position. The wind blows clouds of snow from the exposed cliffs on the right of each mountain. It’s the same snow that gets blown on your face and bites into your right cheek, while the left one only cools out from wind alone. Every other blow lifts part of your coat and chills your intestines. Your right boot has sunken in too deep a snow pile; the usual wetness in the lower inches of your jeans now continues to your right ankle and beyond. Your lips form a smile as your gaze sweeps over the mountaintops. Now at last, the world around you perfectly mirrors the world within.

item.title: Mapfold
item.description:
Ich habe lange kein Erlang mehr geschrieben, jetzt kommt es in einer Vorlesung dran. Als Fingerübung (und zum Testen des Code-Highlightings hier) eine endrekursive mapfold-Implementation.

mapfold(Func, Accu, List) ->
    mapfold(Func, Accu, [], List).

mapfold(Func, Accu, LiAccu, [Head|Tail]) ->
    {NewElem,NewAccu} = Func(Head,Accu),
    mapfold(Func,NewAccu,[NewElem|LiAccu],Tail);
mapfold(_, Accu, LiAccu, []) ->
    {lists:reverse(LiAccu),Accu}.
